author: Misskaos87

title: Raspberry Pi Camera case with mounting holes

description.text:
There are a lot of camera covers for the Pi camera but I needed one that i could mount using simple m3 bolts. I could not find any so I made one.
The tolerances of the parts are set so that if you print it on reasonably fine settings it should snap together without any major post processing. I tried a few others and they were almost impossible to snap together since the tolerances were to tight.
Updates:
2014-11-07 v1
2014-11-09 v2 Distance between both horizontal and vertical mounting holes changed to 30 mm. Fixed that the front part was not a true solid.
2014-11-10 I have made a mounting fixture that uses the holes on the rim of the case to attach a swing arm. The fixture makes it possible to mount the camera at any angle. The mount is found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:536828

author: Lella

description.text: I needed some antenna insulators, so luckily I got a machine that prints plastic things. Of course I wanted them to be a bit special so I put my call sign into them. I did put all the necessary files into a ZIP archive. Just extract and keep them all together in one directory. Enjoy!
It's my 1st realisation.

Tired of not having a place to store your mini-lathe's chuck key? Glue this to the back of your machine and never worry about it again! Improves safety as well - you'll never be tempted to temporarily leave the key in the chuck. Bore diameter is 0.520", scale appropriately. This should fit the default chuck key for the Micro-Mark 7x16 lathe, but it should fit any of the 7x10, 7x12, and 7x14 lathes from Harbor Freight, Seig, LittleMachineShop, and the like.
Also includes a version for an 8mm allen key, used for some tool posts.

This is a fractal thing that can be iterated n number of times in the SCAD file. The cube on the stand prints without support at any size, and, if left unscaled, the stand is easily removed for a well-printed cube.
The Sierpinski cube/menger sponge that has been rotated and put on a stand was designed by BBO, whose thingiverse account is here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/bbo/about
The pictures of the different cube builds are also thanks to BBO. BBO also uploaded a sprued version of the cube (at n=3) so that it will be easy to print and cast in metal. That can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:535927 If you're so inclined. --Printing tips-- -Be conservative with your shells and infill amount when n>3.
-The cube can be printed without support, but the larger your cube is, the more likely it will need support to look nice. Please comment with any problems you experience/suggestions you have for improvement.

comments.text: Have you seen http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:240739 ? It's a similar idea, with a stand that breaks off in separate pieces to make it easy to remove.
comments.author: owens

comments.text: Yes, actually. I remember looking at your sierpinski tetrahedron model when hunting around for iterative scad files. It was helpful when figuring out the math for the sponge.

author: mystrobdr

title: Controller with LCD and SD card - V2

description.text:
This is a controller with a 4 line by 20 character LCD display, SD card and encoder switch with select and back button.
Updated version of my earlier controller http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:293854. Many changes including addition of PCB layout, new back option with SD on top and added small parts.
I have greatly expanded the instructions to include schematics, firmware notes and PCB foils.

Instructions are in a PDF file in "Things"  
Late breaking info: some encoders have frame with 4 dimples which can short to the PCB keeping the select button of the encoder in an "on" condition. Solution id to put some tape covering conductors under the encoder - Kapton tape is good

comments.text: Some encoders have dimples on the metal frame which can short to a conductor on the PCB under the encoder. Work around is to put an insulator such as Kapton tape under the encoder.
comments.author: leadinglights

author: leadinglights

description.header: A simple yet efficient Z coupler !
description.text:
It works with 10mm M3 bolts & nuts.
There are 2 couplers :
  • One is designed for 5mm motor shaft / 8 mm ACME rod : Z-axis-coupler-5x8.stl.
  • One is designed for 5mm motor shaft / 6.4 mm ACME rod : Z-axis-coupler-5x6.4.stl. This coupler is ment for Printrbot Simple & Simple Metal printers but work perfectly fine with other printers with 6.4 mm ACME rod.
  • One is designed for 5mm motor shaft / 5 mm ACME rod : Z-axis-coupler-5x5.stl.
    [Update 03/09/15] : fixed the screw axis closer to the body for a stronger grip on motor shaft & Acme rod (all versions).

• straight up, motor shaft hole at the bottom
  • 2 outside perimeters
  • 30%infill (more flexible) to 50% infill (more rigid)

Check and if you still have this problem, i'll make another one with more tolerance (say 0.3mm). Is that ok ?

author: schrotti

description.text: The other day one of the chairs that I keep around the office broke when sat on. After investigation I found that the part that allows the chair to height adjust had broken in two.  First I tried to epoxy the part back-together but this was not fruitful.  So I decided to model the part up in solid works and print a replacement.  I am very happy with the results and am mostly proud of the inner threads which needed a bit of trial and error to get right but work really well.  The chair works perfectly and will hold an adult male, but you will just have to take my dogs word for it.

A vice (or vise if you prefer) made for light routing or engraving. Made to be CNC cut but a printable (fingers crossed) version has also been uploaded.

See the uploaded parts list for quantities of parts etc. If you make the printed version, you just need one of each of the .stls (I think- let me know if not). Mine was made from 6mm MDF- I don't really think it matters as long as the thickness of certain parts match. 
Cut out all of the MDF parts, stack together as per the GA (glue helps at this point). To ensure alignment use M4 (or equiv.) bolts through the 3.3mm holes. 
Don't glue the bridging bars across the top of the 2 no. M8 nuts- just use bolts fitted from the top into the pre-glued screw_block.  
To hold the anti-lift blocks in place (if you dont want to rely on glue) you'll need to use csk head M4s. Just line everything up and run them through into the moving jaw body. 
I've also uploaded the .stl files for those with printers. The stls have been generated from sub-assemblies of laminated parts. I've tried to combine bodies where possible and checked they open without errors on netfabb so there should be any problems. 
Just noticed- on the dxf the balloons don't contain any part numbers! I've added a .pdf with the parts and their numbers (I''ve had to change the order of the parts as they when on to the sheet (part 7 I think is the only one in the wrong place). 
That's it, enjoy.

description.text: Hucha de Mickey Mouse, con ranura grande que permiter introducir monedas o billetes.

This Bloodhound model is based on the JT format files shared on the bloodhound website (http://www.bloodhoundssc.com/cad-drawings). I used JNetCAD (http://www.johannes-raida.de/jnetcad.htm) to convert the majority of the bodywork.and external JT files to .obj and .stl files. This at least got the files into a format I could work with, but there were still issues with the models. They came through as either solids or collections of surfaces, and there were significant interferences, surface duplications and gaps. I then used a combination of meshmixer (http://www.meshmixer.com/), netfabb basic (http://www.netfabb.com/basic.php), netfabb 'cloud' (https://netfabb.azurewebsites.net/) and Solidworks 2013 (http://www.solidworks.com/) to combine, trim, bridge, split and modify the files until they were 3D printable. I've uploaded the final stl and Solidworks files here. The models are 'full size' so will require significant scaling down to get on your print bed! There is still quite a bit of detail missing, particularly around the rocket exhaust and parachutes area, so if anyone is keen please have a play there.
These models represent at least 30hours of research, editing, and many software crashes, so please provide attributions if you use them for anything interesting. Released with the kind permission of the Bloodhound team.

title: The Last and Best Thomson Super 8 Bearing Block You Will Ever Need and The Last One I Intend To Design

description.text: This is a pillow block for Thomson Super 8 linear ball bushings that fit 1/2" round guide rails.  Not as compact as my other design, this one uses a screw to adjust "fitment" as Thomson's original design does.  The design includes small retention bumps to center the bearing inside the block.

You can see all the important dimensions on the diagram. I sliced using Cura- for some reason slic3r had a hard time with this one. Printed with coex3d MG94 ABS with 0.2mm layers and 30% infill, no support material.
You'll need a 6-32 x 5/8 or 3/4 screw and washer for fitment adjustment. You'll also need 4x 6-32 screws for mounting. The mounting holes are 13mm deep.
Sorry for mixed units- 3D printers want metric measurements but metric hardware is not so common in the US.

remixed_from.author: MiseryBot
remixed_from.title: Filament Guide Pulley for Maketbot or Thing-O-Matic

description.text: A modification of the filament pulley to accept a common 608 zz bearing, m8 bolt and 3/4 inch dowel.

Print a top_holder (make sure you flip over before printing), bottom_holder and 2 copies of the pulley_half.  Glue the pulley and holder pieces together, then put a 608zz bearing in the pulley and secure it to the holder with an m8 bolt.  EDIT: the only difference between the top_holder and bottom_holder files is only the top_holder has the ring to attach to a 3/4 dowel.  This means you can use 2 top_holders instead of 1 of each if you want a ring on each side.
The idea of this is the same as the source; a spool that's too large to be mounted above your printer can instead be routed though the pulley (which itself will be mounted above the printer, this version attaches to a 3/4 inch dowel).  The filament can then be pulled straight down into your extruder, preventing jamming and stalling caused by feeding from the side.
I finished printing it and it works fine!  You'll need a washer for each side of the bearing though (I used more because the only bolt I had was too long.).  All the holes are a little bit tight but I think that's just my printer, and I like them snug anyway.  Just open them up a little bit with your knife / dremel sander / whatever you want.  I ended up printing the pulley in one piece with support which is why the inside looks so rough in the picture.  Another thing to note is that while it fits on a dowel, that doesn't seem to be an ideal configuration.  The extruder moves back and forth so the pulley should swivel a little bit too or extra filament will get fed out.  I dealt with this by zip tying it to the dowel instead of mounting it right on there, this way it has a little wiggle room.

Lasercutter template for a plywood variant of the awesome Google Cardboard (https://cardboard.withgoogle.com/). The result is a far more robust and less grease-prone glimpse into the world of virtual reality! Designed for fabrication from 5mm plywood, to be superglued together during assembly. Use 18mm M3 bolts to attach the round lens grips, and place a 3D print of "VRRing.stl" on top of each lens to prevent them sliding back and forth. A strip of elastic should be stapled across the open end (the one you don't look through) to secure the phone. Works perfectly with my Galaxy Note 2, though for smaller phones you may need to make some sort of cover to seal the unit off from ambient light.

description.text: choppers hat one piece
This is just a proof of concept for creating a simple hinge that is fully printable - the pin itself is made from filament.

1 Print inner part
2 Print outer part
3 Cut a 50mm length of 3mm filament
4 Assemble using the filament as the hinge pin You might need to straighten out the pin first. You can use a single long pin for both hinges, or individual smaller pins for each hinge, which will look better.
Optionally you can thermo-weld (a simple soldering iron you no longer need will do) the ends of the pin to keep it stuck between the hinges, as it might come loose at some point (thanks to JDCUBED for reminding me).

    http://www.digikey.com/product-search/en?KeyWords=3339P-502LF-ND&WT.z_header=search_go
    • for sensorkeyV2, you have two options, this is a really really small part.
  • option1: (printed but haven't tried) print out the wristgears3a_sensorkeyv2 using an SLA printer, like a form1. check www.makexyz.com for local makers that can print this out for you.
  • option2: (verified but tricky) print out wristgears3a_sensorkey_blank, and carve out the cross pattern with a sharp mini exacto blade. I did this as a test. it definitely works, but be very careful!
  • option3: (unverified) make a small amount of thick acetone slurry, print out sensor_blank, stuff acetone slurry into philips slot of trimmer pot, center sensor_blank and press onto slot, let slurry dry and cure for at least 24 hours, carefully remove and clean (plastics on trimmer pot do not react with acetone)
    • Drill out the sensorbracket with a 5/16 bit. the trimmer pot must slide freely for calibration. The cross feature of sensorkey must fit snugly, but not forcefully in the trimmer pot. trim and file to suit. The sensorkey must fit with a bit of play in it. maybe 0.1ish mm per side. it must be able to settle in a bit to mate with the trimmer pot. Disassemble the servo, and attach the external pot in a manner similar to that used for the inmoov bicep, shoulder etc. Assemble rotawrist2:
  • place wristgears3b in rotawrist
  • place sensorkey in sensor gear
  • place sensorgear in rotawrist
  • screw in wristsensorbracket
  • program arduino to activate servo to 90 degrees
  • adjust trimmer pot to where it's centered and the servo stops moving.
  • adjust wristgears3b to angle you want when input is 90 degrees
  • carefully place pot in sensorbracket, and push down until you can feel it engage with the sensorkey
  • carefully rotate pot back and forth until you get zero movement at 9 degrees
  • tighten pot set screw
    *adjust minpulse and max pulse so wrist only turns 180 degrees. otherwise it will make several rotations. my values were 1200 and 1765. that way I can send straight 0 to 180 degree commands.
  • assemble rest of forearm
    *enjoy!
    Tips for tightening tendons
    • When assembling hand to wrist, string up tendons in the palm up position
  • Instructions assume that 0 degrees is palm up, 180 degrees is palm down
  • Instructions assume that for the fingers, 0 degrees is open, 180 degrees is closed
  • Move Wrist servo to 140 degrees
  • Set each finger servo to 40 degrees
  • wire up each open finger tendon and close finger tendon, not loose but doesn't have to be tight
  • using this setup, I have full range of motion in the wrist, and full range for each finger
  • try not to get in the habit of just slamming the finger servos to 0 and 180 degrees. They'll do it in most wrist positions, but they will be too tight to reach wrist 0 and wrist 180. I think the range I'm using is 30 degrees open, 140 degrees closed.
  • be aware that as you approach 0 and 180 for the wrist, you will not
    This is compatible with the newest version of wristgears3b and wristlargev4 and cableholderwristv4, although you will need to cut away part of cabelwristholder so as not to interfere with the wrist sensor assembly
    • 2014-10-25 - updated wristgears_sensor to v2, beefed up the gear horn to it prints better

comments.text: Hey serged, it's the same wrist rotation servo specified for the original wrist rotation mod.  The original wrist rotation design only allowed for about 90 degrees of rotation, due to the gear ratio.  By using the small, multi rotation potentiometer on the opposite side, you can achieve 180 degree wrist rotation.  The built in potentiometer used in the servo is only good for about 180 degrees of rotation on it's own, which isn't enough due to the gear reduction between the servo gear and the wrist gear.  Thanks!

Use these when teaching the young 'uns about various trends among the elements!  The higher the box, the bigger the relative value (biggest = 3 cm high).  
OOPS!  Density was incorrect -- fixed now, at least the individual STL download is fixed -- the ZIP version of density still looks like it must be melting point, and I'm too lazy and have too slow of a connection to fix it!  Sorry for the inconvenience!

I used openscad to create this, using data found on various websites (webelements among others.)  If data wasn't known (see: Darmstadtium) the value was simply left at zero.  One openscad file is included, in case you want to tediously tweak it -- I used excel to build it, and if you want that file, let me know.  The openscad file should be placed in the same directory with write.scad.
The different stl files are renderings of different trends (1st ionization energy, Z effective, etc.)  They are all labelled, but to use them as a "mystery trend" that needs explaining, you could always cover up the label with a piece of duct tape! The corners were warping a little (nothing too serious) on a previous version, and the table wasn't "centered" too well on its base -- it is a little better now.  I printed on a replicator 2 with "natural" filament, and used a sharpie to color the symbols.
(A shout-out to my 3rd, 5th, and 7th period chemistry students!)

We have a Crate and Barrel media center that has two doors that open outward.  There isn't any ventilation and I'm too lazy to cut holes in the back and mount fans, so we leave the doors propped open with a stuffed animal.  The problem is that our baby likes to pull the stuffed animal out, or worse, lean against doors (which means pinched fingers).
I designed a prop piece in OpenSCAD that grabs onto each door, and keeps it a specified distance from the media center frame.  I added holes to the posts so I could put a #6-32 screw in for reinforcement (that's all I had readily available in the garage).

I had left my measurements at home and had to guess.  I was off on the angle, so I couldn't install it as-is.  I ended up using my heat gun to melt the ABS and then put it in place and let the part cool down.

description.text: The trouble with 3D printing a ball bearing is that spheres don't adhere to the 45 degree rule, so they tend to print poorly, or if metal balls are used instead, then the bearing requires assembly. This is a new kind of bearing that can only be manufactured by 3D printing and comes preassembled. It is a planetary gearset and functions like a cross between a needle bearing and a thrust bearing. No cage is required to keep the rollers in place, because their gearing keeps them perfectly spaced. The gears are all herringbone, which is why it cannot be disassembled and also why it can act as a thrust bearing. If you're wondering how well a 3D printed bearing could work under load, please check out my video: http://youtu.be/ZghwSBiM0sU This design is fully parametric and made to be adjusted in the Customizer app to whatever you need. Thanks to aubenc for finding a problem in the first version.

The key to any bearing is the tolerance between the moving parts. Since this is printed all at once, you want the minimum tolerance possible, where any less would fuse the parts together. I print these with the MakerWare medium defaults on my Replicator 1 and it requires a fair bit of torque to break it free at first. It's designed to fit onto the standard English hex size for screwdriver bits, so you can use a tool to help turn it. Running it in a drill for a few minutes helps to smooth out the rotation. 
You can adjust the tolerance in Customizer if you need. You can also change the dimensions, numbers of planets, numbers of teeth, etc. Normal gears use a small pressure angle in order to transmit torque, but here I use a large pressure angle so that they transmit force better (hence why they look more pointed than usual). Your chosen number of sun gear teeth is approximate because planetary gearboxes turn out to be quite constrained in terms of what tooth numbers will fit. See the beginning of my code for the equation I came up with.

comments.text: I have printed the 6 gear (bearing6.stl) version 5 different times on my Ultimaker 2 Extended.  I have never customized the the file at all.  Using the silver PLA material that came with the printer resulted in a part that would not turn freely, but could be loosened with considerable work, by striking it repeatedly about the circumference of the ring gear with a wooden malley on a hard wood surface.  Patience and perseverance were the key here,  When it finally broke loose it took some work first with an allen wrench by hand and then with a cordless drill.  Soft Scrub liquid cleanser really turned it into a working part. The result was a bearing with little or no end play and a smooth operation.  That said, two of the parts were made using PLA from two other sources SHAXON and MatterHackers that produced loose to very loose assemblies right off of the printer bed using exactly the same gcode file.  It appears that the material selected has a significant impact on the final result.  Perhaps it's a difference in shrinkage?

comments.text: Well, it prints great on my printers (Makerbot and Printrbot), as it does for many of the others who have commented here. This is a difficult test of printer calibration, and those who have been successful have worked hard for it. It's hard to make a desktop 3D printer respect a 0.2mm gap, but it is possible. I'm working toward a time when all 3D printers come calibrated accurately enough to do this out of the box, but that day is not quite here yet. Without tough tests, we'll never get there.

comments.text: Emmett did a great job on this gear.  I printed three of them.  One in PLA, one in ABS and one in Taulman Nylon 618.  Very cool stuff.  The PLA was printed at the default settings as in the SCAD file.  ABS needed the clearance set to 0.2mm, and the nylon needed 0.25 (minimum).  All three printed beautifully and work very well, although the nylon should probably use 0.3 for clearance as it is a bit snug, showing zero play between any of the gears and it broke loose very easily when turned.  All prints used a .4mm E3D nozzle in my Hexagon hot-end and were sliced & printed with Simplify3D v3.02.  All filament was 1.75mm.  I used Elmer's Xtreme Glue Stick for the bed adhesion.

comments.text: I finally got this working on my Printrbot jr.  The problem was I was using Repetire-Host Mac 0.56 which comes with version 0.99 Slice3r.  This version of Slice3r has a bug which attaches the small gears to the outer gear.  I installed Slice3r V1.0 separately, changed preferences in Repetire to use the new Slice3r and now it works.  I set fill density to 1 and Solid infill every 1 layers, combine infill every 1 layers, Extrusion multiplier .7

comments.author: nwlaurie

comments.text: Calibrate, calibrate, calibrate.  Even two printers from the same company that ship at the same time could have subtle differences, and so too with the filament.  Print out some test pieces and make sure you're all good, and then print out more tricky stuff.  When you calibrate your machine well, and run slower to avoid wiggling your setup, the results are usually quite good on the first try -- but you have to get those calibrations done well first and foremost.

title: Compressor Wheel
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Disclaimer:
Due to the recent incidents (things appearing on ebay) I just want to make something very clear:
I do not allow any commercial use of my STL-files, my designs and my photos! Description:
I wanted a quality calibration and demonstration thing for my 3D printer. And there are a lot of calibration things on thingiverse. But most of them are quite abstract and this is really booooring. So I designed something more realistic, something that lets me try different slicer settings and then directly see the results. And of course something I know how it should look like when printed.
EDIT:
I added a flat-laying version.

Use your slicer and rotate the compressor wheel by 90Â° so that it lies plain on your bed.
For an easy print set it to a scale of 75% or even 100% with a layer height of 0.2mm.
If you want a more challenging print, try a scale of 50% and 0.05mm layer height.
These are my settings:
Ultimaker 3D printer (V1 hot end / V2 extruder)
Cooling with two fans
Gold PLA from faberdashery @ 200Â°C
50% scale
0.8mm wall
0.05mm layer height
10% fill
45 mm/s print speed
(60 min print time / 3g weight)

Lulzbot ships a handy and quite complete tool kit with their printers. Unfortunately they come stored in a zippered pouch that makes finding tools a bit of a hassle. 
I designed this desktop tool holder with specific slots for each of the most common used tools from the kit, plus space for a few more. 
I designed mine to be secured to the top of a wooden drawer box that I will custom build. 
I included the sketchup files in case anyone wanted to modify it.

Print out the top and the bottom, glue together, enjoy. 
All files ran through Netfabb. 
Top print time is about 2 hours on a stock configured Lulzbot AO-100 with the bottom taking about 5 hours.

Plastic parts for the Prusa i3 kit I sell (http://www.emakershop.com/Seller=801). Edits to the original (https://github.com/josefprusa/Prusa3, https://github.com/josefprusa/Prusa3-vanilla, extruder: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:18379):
  • minimal Prusa i3 x ends: zip ties, built-in adjustable tensioner and easy z height adjustor (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:500550)
  • increased height on y corners to avoid clearance issue with bed mountings.
  • combined mounting holes for hot end -> extruder & extruder -> x-carriage (uses M5x40 bolts).
  • strengthened and lengthened extruder idler arms.
  • widened a 608ZZ bearing hole on the extruder a bit so it fits better.
    UPDATE 2015-01-30: Added new endstop holders for v1.2 endstop with PCB - see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:659231. Use i3xyze14 for these, and the older version (i3xyze13) if you have just the switches (can cable tie x and y to smooth rods).
    • Source files here: https://github.com/gcolbourn/Prusa3-SemiU Note you can use the Split function in Slic3r to take just the parts you need from the build plate STLs provided here. UPDATE 2015-04-24: Added extra parts needed for Box Frame (12mm plywood) version of i3: i3box_extras2.stl (note you won't need the z parts from the i3xyze14.stl file if you're building one of these). UPDATE 2015-04-29: Added extruder body and idler for 1.75mm filament: eg175_4.stl (use 4mm OD, 2mm ID PTFE tube between hobbed bolt and hot end).
